title: Add FUSE (Filesystem in Userspace) support in WSL
body:
Please add FUSE (Filesystem in Userspace) interface /dev/fuse into WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux).
With FUSE, we can access from WSL to file storages regularly used with Linux cluster environments such as GlusterFS, Moose FS, etc.

comments.body: +1! This will enable the use of the super handy SSFHS
Would be incredibly helpful to have access to sshfs, which requires FUSE.

It actually works with WSL2, BUT you can't use fuse under WSL2 to have a remote linux FS accessible to Windows programs.
The Fuse mountponit is only visible with the linux Kernel, the windows Kernel still see the folder before folder mount.

WSL 2 is not a viable response to this feature request. WSL 2 defeats the whole purpose of Windows Subsystem for Linux because it's just a Hyper-V VM of Linux with a VHD for a rootfs, which means if you use any other virtualisation product or actually support the ENTIRE POINT of WSL you can't use WSL 2
yes please add fuse asssap! thank you

It looks like FUSE support will come in WSL 2, available through the Windows insider program by the end of June 2019.
Source: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/commandline/announcing-wsl-2/
please add FUSE, required by Appimage

It is there already. Look into using FUSE for Windows from Crossmeta https://www.crossmeta.io/fuse-for-windows/
It already has sshfs and fuse-nfs for nfs clients and s3backer for access to cloud storage s3 or azure blobs.
All the file systems are visible from WSL as /mnt/v/
All software produced at CERN is available through the cvmfs distributed file system which is based on FUSE. Without FUSE it is impossible for me to use WSL for real work.
SSHFS support is a big deal for migrating to using a Windows machine instead of my company's Ubuntu ones.
How come this is one of the only 2 ideas that have 2000+ votes and not something WSL team even acknowledges? So much for using uservoice @wsl
